title: 106_hr5319
content:
The "Teachers For Tomorrow Act of 2000" is introduced to revise teacher loan forgiveness programs by expanding loan forgiveness for teachers. The "Teachers For Tomorrow Act of 2000" aims to expand loan forgiveness eligibility for teachers to provide incentives for individuals to enter and stay in the teaching profession. The Secretary will assume the obligation to repay a qualified loan amount for new borrowers who are full-time teachers in public elementary or secondary schools. The "Teachers For Tomorrow Act of 2000" expands loan forgiveness eligibility for teachers in public schools based on their relevant subject area and teaching skills certified by the school's chief administrative officer. The "Teachers For Tomorrow Act of 2000" expands loan forgiveness eligibility for teachers in public schools based on their teaching skills in various subjects, state certification or license, and loan repayment selection criteria set by the Secretary. The Secretary will repay a percentage of the loan obligation for teachers who complete each school year of teaching. The repayment percentage varies based on the years of service and the type of school where the teaching occurs. The repayment percentage for teachers varies based on years of service and the type of school. Loan amounts for consolidation loans can be considered qualified only if used to repay specific types of loans for eligible borrowers. The Secretary can issue regulations for determining years of service for continuing education loans. The section does not allow for any refunding of loan repayments. The Secretary may use the previous year's list of schools for service determination if the current year's list is not available before May 1. Teachers can continue to teach in a school that no longer meets eligibility requirements and still be eligible for loan forgiveness. Borrowers cannot receive benefits under both this section and another for the same service. The section defines a "year" for teacher service and authorizes appropriations for fiscal years. Additionally, a new section is added to the Higher Education Act regarding direct student loans. "Expanded loan forgiveness for teachers under SEC. 460A." The purpose of this section is to expand eligibility for loan forgiveness for teachers to provide incentives for individuals to enter and stay in the teaching profession. The Secretary is authorized to cancel repayment obligations for qualified loan amounts for new borrowers of Federal Direct Stafford Loans and Federal Direct Unsubsidized Stafford Loans who are full-time teachers. The section aims to broaden loan forgiveness eligibility for full-time teachers in public schools, with specific criteria for elementary and secondary school teachers based on their subject area and teaching skills. The Secretary shall establish a formula for selecting borrowers for loan repayment based on availability, ensuring fairness and equality. Loan forgiveness eligibility for full-time teachers in public schools is broadened, with specific criteria for elementary and secondary school teachers based on subject area and teaching skills. The Secretary will cancel a percentage of the loan obligation for teachers after each school year, with specific percentages based on the years of service and school qualifications. The Secretary will cancel a percentage of the loan obligation for teachers based on years of service and school qualifications. Loan amounts for Federal Direct Consolidation Loans may qualify if used to repay specific types of loans. The Secretary can cancel a portion of a teacher's loan based on years of service and school qualifications. Regulations may be issued to implement this section, and it does not allow for any loan repayment refunds. The Secretary may use the previous year's list if service determination is not available before May 1. Teachers can still be eligible for loan forgiveness if they continue to teach in a school that meets certain requirements. Borrowers cannot receive benefits from both this section and another act for the same service. The term 'year' for teacher service is defined by the Secretary. Appropriations are authorized for fiscal year 2002 and the following 5 years. SEC. 3. NO INCOME TAX BY REASON OF LOAN FORGIVENESS

Amendment to the Internal Revenue Code exempts teachers from paying income tax on forgiven loans under specific sections of the Higher Education Act of 1965.
